physDesc.p: This is a two page, typewritten letter with the words “Poetry” and “Monroe” penciled in at the top left corner of the page. The letter has no rips or tears in throughout the pages.

div.p: Your letter has come, and I am much amused to read the program of Mr. Carpenter’s Symphony. I am afraid I have no pull in getting it performed. Mr. Higginson and Dr. Muck arrange that between them, and I do not think they are either of them very open to suggestion, so I am afraid I cannot help you there, but doubtless Mr. Carpenter’s Symphony will get a performance on its own merits before long.

It was very nice of you to get my letter into the April number. It was not so much that I wanted to get it in, as that I felt I ought to get it in. You see it gives me a certain amount of pull to be known as the editor of that “Anthology”, and I felt I ought to disavow it as soon as possible out of fairness to the others.

I am sorry the advertisement for “The Egoist” got there late. It was not my fault but the fault of the mail. I did not receive it in time, which is too bad. I suppose Miss Weaver will be furious with me, but then if she had paid a little more attention to her steamers, she would have seen that it was a very risky thing to send it to me.
That Imagist number of “The Egoist” is going to be very good I think. You ought to take notice of it in your editorials.

I wanted to ask you to let me review Fletcher’s book for you, but as he has just given me such a send-off, I was afraid it would look like a trade, so I have asked Margaret Anderson to let me review it for her instead.

In the current number of “The Egoist” there is a remarkable poem by Paul Fort called “Le Chant des Anglais”. As you do not ever reprint things in “Poetry” could not you bring it in an editorial somehow and comment on it. “The Egoist” has such a small circulation that it will never be seen unless you mention it. I read it yesterday in my last lecture, which was on Paul Fort with the result that most of my audience were in tears.
I wish I could see you. Aren’t you coming east.
